reviewText: This is one of the HBO feature-length films that keep nagging at me to get a TV with HBO and History Channel and a few other good things.As most people know by now, Temple Grandin was diagnosed with autism at the age of four. The doctor who diagnosed her pronounced it like a life sentence. Her mother was simply not having any of this "put her in an institution" (implied: and forget about her), and gradually adapted home-schooling methods to her needs. We see the boarding high school and how others came to accept her -- or not -- and her college. But the most interesting part comes after she realizes what she wants to do is study animal husbandry, in part because she found a high level of rapport with the animals on her aunt's ranch when she spent the summer there between high school and college.Temple was not only brilliant, but lucky. She had a few teachers and other mentors who showed up at the right times to give her a chance. Not that there weren't problems; there were plenty. One big one was that her stock handling designs were revolutionary, built to reduce the stress and fear in the animals right up to the moment of slaughter. The ignorance and, in some cases, wanton cruelty of some of the stock handlers was appalling.Her first really original design was for a dipping system where cattle could be put into a flea bath without trauma, and swim quite placidly to the other end, climb out on their own, and not drown or panic or cause problems for the handlers. She demonstrated it for a stockman's journalist the day before the official showing, and it worked beautifully. The writer was very impressed, and wrote a very favorable article. But the next day, which was supposed to be the regular press briefing and demonstration, the stock handlers changed her design in all the wrong ways before she even arrived on the scene. They completely ruined it, so that the only record of the real design was in the magazine article by the guy who had seen it the day before.When she came to apply her principles to the animals heading into the slaughter house, she also encountered resistance. The first argument, predictably, was that it would be too expensive. But she stood up to them and pointed out all the ways they would save money in the long run, and eventually they bought into the ideas.The last scene may indeed be the best. Temple and her mother go to an Autism conference, and in typical Temple manner, she spoke up to correct a speaker's blatant error. Someone naturally asked her how old her child was, and when she said she didn't have any children, they smirked on the assumption that she had no idea what she was talking about. But when she began to tell her story, including the fact that she had both a bachelor's and master's degree, and was working on a doctorate, they wanted to hear everything.This wonderful woman is a living testament to the idea that we must take people seriously for their abilities and their spirit, not dismiss them as a diagnosis. She's used her autism to her advantage in many ways, and to the advantage of animals everywhere, and the people who love them and the people who eat them. As she says several times in the film, "Nature is cruel, but there's no reason we have to be."

reviewText: It's always inspiring - and humbling - to see someone overcome great odds with native-intelligence and courage. Even though afflicted with autism, Temple Grandin thought her life ought to count for something. And she made it happen - on both personal and professional levels. Supported at-arm's-length by her mother's love and wisdom and encouraged by others close to her, Temple battled her way though high-school, then college; eventually earning not only a Ph.D. but the admiration and gratitude of countless people dealing with autism. Using unique abilities bestowed/burdened upon her by autism, she envisioned equipment and processes that would allow beef cattle to live without fear or discomfort right up to the second they "leave" (to wherever they go when their bodies become simply beef). Because Temple also correctly envisioned and sold the concept of increased cost-efficiency to business people around the country, her equipment and processes are employed today at nearly half of all slaughterhouses in America.I thought the movie extremely well done. While it incidentally (and entertainingly) sheds needed light on a couple of the myriad difficulties that confront those with autism, the film's strength is in the story of a remarkable woman who, when she "leaves" (to go wherever), will have left her corner of the world better off than when she came. Her story is a source of hope and enlightenment in this age when autism appears to be on the rise, but it's easy to imagine that Temple Grandin's story might also inspire others - autistic or otherwise - to live lives that personally "count for something".

reviewText: This wonderful film is appropriate for people between the ages of 15 and 115. I strongly recommend that schools buy copies of it (1) for teachers to show in social studies classes and (2) for students to check out from their school libraries.This film's true story is a great one about a young woman with "different" abilities, who earns a Ph.D. and succeeds in a world-class way in a so-called "man's world." The acting in TEMPLE GRANDIN is uniformly excellent, with Claire Danes as a shining stand-out. Along the way, most viewers will find they are learning a lot about what it means to be a "human being" and what the phrase "humane treatment" really means. And many viewers will frequently find they are very deeply touched--and even getting misty-eyed.Anyone who has seen this bio-pic will have an array of favorite scenes she or he would like to discuss with others (on HBO, I've viewed it start-to-finish 3 times and have watched parts of it at other times). Two of my own favorite scenes are Temple Grandin discussing her "squeeze machine" with her new blind roommate, and Temple Grandin getting press credentials that allow her access to places she was forbidden to enter. I could easily list two dozen more. And who can forget the film's wise message that "different" doesn't automatically mean "less"?I hope that many high school libraries and public libraries will buy DVD copies of TEMPLE GRANDIN--if yours do not, you might urge them to do so--or you might donate a copy to them. Speaking as a retired teacher, I strongly recommend that public schools buy copies for classroom viewing, so that young students can have a chance to watch and discuss this truly great film.CAUTION: because of the intensity of some stockyard scenes, some people under the ages of 13 or 14 might not be mature enough yet to view them.

reviewText: Claire Danes. Sigh. I'm not ashamed to admit that I am smitten by this beautiful woman, and we see her too infrequently. She should be the Kate Hepburn of our era, but alas....In this HBO Films presentation, Claire takes on the title role of autistic professor Temple Grandin, a lady I nearly ran into up in Fort Collins, Colorado, and who awarded me the privilege of reading one of my manuscripts. A very fine, capable person.Claire Danes reaches into some strange places to play Dr. Grandin--the semblance is spooky. Never have I seen such an uncanny biographical performance. She speaks with the same grating shout, suffers through the same mannerisms and the whole (briefly told) story of Dr. Grandin's childhood is well presented.It is a shame this film did not move beyond the time period it represents: when Dr. Grandin published her book "Emergence: Labeled Autistic", she was panned as a fraudster who had no idea what autism was. Experts the world over wound up with egg on their faces thanks to Dr. Grandin, though of course no one person can be the universal voice of any illness or condition. Danes shows just how hard it is simply to live life in accordance with normal rules, which Dr. Grandin learned to mould into her own rules of engagement.David Strathairn, whom I love, turns in a fine little-bit-more-than-cameo as one of Grandin's early teachers, Professor Carlock. Catherine O'Hara, in an unusual dramatic turn, plays Dr. Grandin's Aunt Ann beautifully, and Julia Ormond is very palatable as well. No shortage of talent here.I originally awarded this 3 stars, because I did not like the facile, dismissive tone of the thing. Grandin had a most unpleasant childhood and a rough pre- and post-adolescent life; this film hints at very little of that. VERY little. In deference to the actual discrepancy, I have changed my rating to four stars. It shows very little of her college life, and her interesting concept of "Sins of the System" should have at least been mentioned.What is here is solid, meat-n-potatoes work as I like to call it, with straightforward cinematography and a well-matched soundtrack. Though the makers didn't torture us with what-it's-like-to-be-autistic, they do a marvelous job showing us pictorial thinking. Viewers will love Grandin's thinking and invention processes. Also penetrating is a look into the slaughterhouse industry as it was decades ago, and how Dr. Grandin changed it overnight. She's even contributed to better kosher slaughtering procedure.Get this interesting, gently paced film and pay attention. You won't see a more heroic and fascinating story for some time to come.And you will learn things about autism you could never imagine.

reviewText: TEMPLE GRANDIN has a committed following group of admirers of fine film making: the reason the group is not larger is that this little film is a 'made for TV' movie and that at times puts it into the 'inconsequential' category in people's minds.  Nothing could be further from the truth. The film deals with autism in an honest, extremely sympathetic and intelligent way.  While there have been other films that deal with the various forms of autistic behavior ('Adam', 'Rainman', 'What's Eating Gilbert Grape', I am Sam', 'The Other Sister', 'Forest Gump', 'Little Man Tate' to name a few of the better known ones), few succeed on the level of this beautifully written adaptation of autobiographical books by the title character Dr. Temple Grandin (adapted by Christopher Monger and Merritt Johnson). It is fearless in its discussion of autism and for once shows how the autistic mind can function (for Temple, it functions in pictures and leads to a highly successful career as a scientist) in a manner that can be an incredible resource for mankind.  It simply works on every level, much to the sensitivity of director Mick Jackson who seems to understand the complexities of the mind of the central character as well as the responses of all of the ancillary characters.Claire Danes BECOMES Temple Grandin, so fine is her acting and her ability to bring the audience (and the cast of characters) into the inner workings of the autistic mind. reviewText: First and foremost, I need to emphasize that this film works on so many levels it is difficult to isolate the separate strands of knowledge that we acquire in the viewing. reviewText: This is an absolutely well done and quite inspiring movie. It isn't sentimental and Claire Danes does a superb job as Temple Grandin (in fact, I didn't even recognize her at first) as does David Strathairn as the integral teacher who helped Temple transition from home to school and also advocated for her when other teachers were skeptical.It is worth noting, early on, that viewers can opt to hear the actual Temple Grandin, not the actress, describing her reaction to every scene of the movie. We watched it both ways and each has so much to offer. Temple's reaction to the movie is very engaging. Now more about the movie....Claire Danes,in her role as Temple, shows how challenging every part of life could be for someone with autism,from childhood on. I hope this one goes far to help people understand the enigma that is autism and to stop fearing someone who looks and acts so differently. I am especially in awe of how the director and actors didn't sugar coat the realities of autism. I watched this with one son who asked, "What is wrong with her?" and came away from the movie with a new understanding of autism.Every part of this movie reveals a new challenge for Temple and that makes it riveting. She has trouble adapting to the smallest changes. She doesn't like to be touched. Going through doors, especially automatic ones, is terrifying. Other students in college tease her. Again, Claire Danes shines in her role, never breaking character. This movie belongs in the library of anyone who has an autistic child, teachers of special ed students and anyone who wants to watch a superb film.However (and I still believe this movie deserves a 5 star review), I have a few quibbles, minor ones. I do think both parents of autistic children and others need to realize that Temple is what is called "high functioning." Even so, she might never have gotten so far without the support of her mother and others who weren't put off by her behavior.But not every autistic child can do the same, in spite of their parents' best efforts, in spite of the best treatments possible, in spite of thinking outside the box. If this movie causes people to feel that every autistic child can - or,even worse, MUST -reach Grandin's level, then they don't realize that research into causes and treatments for autism are still evolving.Everyone wants those with autism to succeed and be accepted but parents of an autistic child should never feel guilty if their child doesn't become as successful as Grandin. As long as it doesn't induce that kind of guilt, the movie stands on its own as a portrait of a very remarkable woman.This movie is inspiring because it shows that some autistic children can learn to function in "our" world even though they see the world in a very different way or as the Temple of the movie says, "Different ....but not less than." What an apt way to describe what every one of us who has or knows an autistic child would wish!Since autism covers both high functioning and low functioning children, the prognosis for some autistic children is not necessary as hopeful as that of Temple Grandin. Temple became a respected expert in livestock behavior. Some autistic children may not get that far, through no fault on anyone's part.I have some experience with this. We had a child who was called "autistic" even though we didn't adopt him until he was older. He rocked, flapped his arms, didn't seem too engaged with people, etc. However, his "autism" was caused by being raised in an institution for 5 years. Now he behaves like any child his age. At the SAME time, others who were adopted at his age never grew out of their autistic behavior. They remained locked inside their minds even though their parents tried every bit as hard as we did to help those children. Their children are still diagnosed as autistic and behave no differently than many autistic children. They do not engage with other people. They rock. They have tantrums if anything in their environment changes.Point being: the brain is mysterious and so is autism. Whatever its cause, it has varying degrees of severity, depending on the child. So by all means, watch this move and be inspired by it. But do not take it as a promise that any child with autism will become a Temple Grandin.I plan to have several copies of this one, some to hand out because the movie is simply that wonderful.
summary: A must see! Here is what those with or without autistic children need to know, however.

reviewText: Temple Grandin,  professor, renowned consultant to the beef industry, and author, could not even speak a word until she turned four years old. Her mother had the great misfortune, not of suffering because of a "disabled" child, but of suffering through medical and "mental health" professionals with wrong-headed and blaming attitudes.  TG was born in 1950, and the prevailing professional attitude of the times was that the affliction of autism was caused by "cold, non-nurturing  mothers" who fail to bond with the child.  A child diagnosed as autistic (called "infantile schizophrenia" in those days!) was thought to be "hopeless"; and the best solution was believed to be to institutionalize and forget about the child. Well, fortunately for Temple and the rest of the world, her mother KNEW that she did not cause her daughter's autism, and furthermore, she knew that her daughter was bright. Just how bright she was would be revealed as Temple's mom pushed her to learn and to go beyond her comfort zone, and, as the film has it, she learned to think, "It's just another door. I can go through it."The film focuses quite a bit on Temple's school years, through the private boarding school in NH (where her science teacher becomes her advocate and mentor), to her victory in graduating from college (after seriously resisting attending), on to get a master's in animal science from Arizona State U. (where it is so hot that she couldn't believe that people live there!), and beyond. Obviously Temple does learn to talk and to function in the world of people, but she is still more at home in the world of animals. She bonds with the horses at her private school, and then goes on to focus on cattle (her favorite animal) and the humane treatment of beef cattle.Much of the film focuses on her development of a "squeeze machine"; a self-comforting devise she designs after she saw how cattle calmed down when herded into a mechanism that encloses the cow into a mechanical holding devise. Autistic people are normally unable to tolerate human touch, and have sensory issues in general.  But TG is impressed by the calming effect of the simple machine, she goes on to construct her personal "hug machine".  It turns out to be quite an uphill battle to get the authorities at school to let her keep one in her room.The movie shows how, despite the extreme social difficulties of high school, and TG's love of living and working at her aunt's ranch--and sameness in general--her mother helps her see going forward to college and beyond as "just another door to go through."  In this manner, she imagines each major step literally as a door she could walk through, and she manages to do so.I really enjoyed this movie, and not only is it a great introduction to Temple Grandin and her work, but I think it is a profound statement about the value of the individual who is "different".
summary: "A Door Opened, and I went through it"

reviewText: In the realm of made-for-TV movies, there is no question that HBO has been leading the way with critically acclaimed and Emmy nominated fare within recent years.  Take 2010, for example, with HBO's "The Pacific" ruling in the mini-series category--three other HBO productions were left battling it out in the film subdivision.  "You Don't Know Jack," a Barry Levinson biopic about assisted-suicide maverick Jack Kevorkian, netted 15 Emmy nominations and won Al Pacino a statue as Best Actor.  "Temple Grandin," another biopic--this one about the autistic Grandin who became a pioneer in animal husbandry--also garnered 15 nods and was the night's big winner.  In addition to Outstanding Made For Television Movie, it won Best Actress for Claire Danes as well as supporting statuettes for David Strathairn and Julia Ormond.  And finally, there was "The Special Relationship," depicting the bond between Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, which was a bridesmaid with five nominations and no wins.  All in all, a good showing for HBO!Arguably the film with the highest profile and most distinguished pedigree of the three is "You Don't Know Jack."  Interestingly enough, it is also my least favorite.  There is certainly nothing wrong with "Jack" and I learned quite a bit about Kevorkian, who to my mind is darn near a saint.  From a surprisingly humble beginning, Kevorkian was a trailblazer and with single-minded purpose became a figurehead in groundbreaking legal debates about medical ethics.  It's a great and fascinating story, but Levinson gives it a surprisingly by-the-numbers presentation.  Anyone familiar with the routine cadence of a biopic will agree that this one ticks all the expected boxes.  Pacino is refreshingly restrained and, for the first time in years, brings an understated dignity to a role.  He does well capturing the unprepossessing doctor and he is ably assisted by John Goodman, Brenda Vaccaro, and Susan Sarandan.  "You Don't Know Jack" is a good film that's at its best when looking at the quietly intimate moments of Kevorkian's patients."Temple Grandin," on the other hand, is the most unexpected of the three films.  I was fearful that "Grandin" might be a bit like medicine--good for me but not very fun.  But not so!  Both heartfelt and entertaining, this film pulses with life.  In an interesting visual style, it attempts to connect the viewer to how Grandin's mind visualizes things.  Unique in its presentation, it's also a dynamic narrative device!  Claire Danes does her best work in years--it's a showy role, but she doesn't showboat.  And like Pacino, Danes does a nice job of approximating the real life inspiration.  Grandin's story is terrific too.  She overcomes so much as a woman, as someone with autism, as someone who seems incapable of normalcy.  Through sheer perseverance and stubbornness, she made people listen and became an industry leader in the humane treatment of livestock.  Fascinating stuff, really--makes me wish I had a bit more gumption.And then we have the utterly charming "The Special Relationship."  Another film that is far more engaging than one might predict, "Relationship" plays almost like a sly comedy of manners.  A terrific Michael Sheen plays Tony Blair--and really who else could play Blair?  This is his third collaboration as Blair with screenwriter Peter Morgan.  A young Blair is infatuated with Bill Clinton (nicely done by Dennis Quaid) and adopts much of his style from his mentor.  The two form a friendship with Clinton in the driver's seat, but through the years as scandal strikes--there is a delicate shift in balance that makes for a role reversal.  Topical and true to the historical events, "Relationship" is also a smart and amusing riff on male bonding.  Morgan continues to be one of our strongest writers so it's no surprise that this is a literate and winning film.  Hope Davis also does a good Hillary.All in all, these are three worthwhile films.  Maybe it would make a fun biopic triple feature.  "Jack" ranks about 3 1/2 stars--nice but conventional.  "Grandin" would be about 4 1/2 stars--director Mick Jackson does wonders with the visual aspects of the film.  And "Relationship" would fall in between at 4 stars for making recent history seem new again.  Keep it up HBO!  KGHarris, 10/10.
summary: Three HBO Films Keep It Real--"Grandin" Deserves A Hug

reviewText: Claire Danes is superb as Temple Grandin, the animal husbandrist born 1947 in Boston and designer of humane cattle processing plants. This film, released in 2010 by HBO Films, traces Grandin's life from her early years in Boston through 1981, when she spoke at a national conference on autism, the disability she carries in her life. It shows the beginning of her career as a scientist and advocate for autism and humane treatment of farm animals she discusses in her many books on the subjectAnimals Make Us Human: Creating the Best Life for Animals.The HBO made for broadcast film covers Grandin's youth, her years in boarding school and college, her pursuit of bachelor's and master's degrees at Arizona State University, and her early years in the cattle business where she strived to merge humane treatment for animals doomed to be food with solid science and business purposes. This is not a story about a bleeding heart animal lover; in contrast, it tells the story of a solid pragmatist, a scientist that works for better ways to manage animals raised for human food while paying the respect to the animals she believes they deserve. Grandin has gone on to revolutionize the way animals are treated in stockyards and in slaughterhouses, designing facilitiies that are more humane and at the same time more economically efficient.What is best in this film is the way it visualizes Grandin's brain at work. She sees the world in pictures, not in text or imagery. Even though I formerly worked for a state mental health agency that treated, among other things, autistic children, I was never sure exactly what the disability was. This film helped me understand its hold on people and how overstimulation in social situations is one of its more devastating consequences. You see this played out over and over again in the film, where Danes, as Grandin, is consistently at odds with a chaotic world in social situations but is completely in command of the world where she can visualize answers to significant intellectual questions.While I read her profile on Wikipedia, I don't know enough about Grandin to tell if the film is alwasy accurate in what it portrays. If it is, Grandin related more readily, in some respects, to other mammals than people. She learned early in life that the containment crate cattle go into (for branding or shots) calms them; she experimented with this on herself and found it had the same effect on her. reviewText: Claire Danes was a much-heralded actress when she made her major film debut alongside Leonardo DiCaprio in 1996.  Then for a while she seemed to fade into the woodwork.  "Temple Grandin" is a strong and welcome reaffirmation of Danes' abilities as an actress.As evidenced by the many reviews here, this is a disarming, straightforward little film about an individual's triumph over disability.  Of course, the message the movie carries is not so much about a misunderstood "disability" as it is about the simple condition of being "different".  Midway through the movie we see a large, prominent photograph of Albert Einstein in Temple Grandin's living quarters.  Point taken.  Einstein suffered from epilepsy; he was different.  If you can't appreciate difference, how can you recognize genius?Temple Grandin has autism, but she is gifted with the ability to instinctively think like an engineer.  She finds a solution to help quiet her problems of anxiety when she visits a cattle farm as a teenager.  Having empathy for the animals, but no understanding of human mannerisms, she elects to pursue a career in animal science.Much of the movie concerns her struggles to overcome the shortsighted, virulent chauvinism of western cattlemen that she seeks to work with in Arizona.  But, showing an incredible mix of resolve, pluck, and ingenuity, she manages to prevail.Claire Danes, playing Grandin, keeps a preternaturally alert expression on her face, betraying both fear and curiosity.  Danes also appears to have lost considerable weight to take on the role of a person who subsists on a diet of yogurt, pudding, and jello.  Julia Ormond is luminously beautiful as Grandin's loving and sympathetic mother;  David Strathairn is also effective as a teacher who spots Grandin's intellectual potential.This movie is a clear winner on all counts, with one minor detraction for me.  The musical score is a stale, numbing take on Philip Glass' minimalism.  Though it may have been intended to convey a sense of Grandin's inner struggles and determination, I found it instead to be merely irritating.  A minor complaint, but it did affect my appreciation of an otherwise stellar film.

reviewText: I have to ask that question. Where did she get that name, Temple, in the first place? It's an odd name but just asking. Anyway Clare Danes is completely unrecognizable as the autistic genius Temple Grandin whose age ranges from 14 to 40 in this movie. This movie is truly an inspiration about Temple's amazing life. First, she's diagnosed with autism at 4 years old and suggested to be sent to a mental hospital. Her mother (played wonderfully by Julia Ormond) refuses to do so and works hard at reaching her. I don't know the exact moment when Temple started talking but she doesn't quit.As she gets older, Temple is sent to a boarding school where she gets to ride horses and bonds with science teacher, Professor/Doctor Carlock, (played beautifully by David Staitharn). He reaches out to her as a friend, teacher, and mentor as well.Temple spends a summer on her Aunt and Uncle's cattle ranch in Arizona. There she has an epiphany with the livestock. Her aunt is played by Catherine O'Hara. The film shows how Temple's mind thinks in visual pictures and how she relates to the world.She goes to Franklin Pierce College in New Hampshire where she must prove her machine helps her to calm down. She goes to graduate school for animal husbandry in Arizona where she encounters sexism, male chauvinism, and harsh treatment in a predominantly male-dominated field. Even though Temple dresses like a cowgirl almost all of the time and eats jello or yogurt, she doesn't fit with the guys nor does she try. She's much happier with the animals particularly the cattle that goes to slaughter. Temple's driven to improve the cattle's final days at the slaughterhouses.At the same time, Temple's demeanor is often strange because of her autism. She lives with it but it doesn't define her existence. That's the what the message is all about. This movie does prove how far Temple was determined to go.In the special features, I wished that they added more about Temple's life, a biography, or more to understand her. They offer a brief five minutes of the making of the film.Still, it's an extraordinary piece of film-making that would have easily won a Best Actress Academy Award for Clare Danes but she was already awarded an Emmy and Golden Globe Award for her performance in this role. Hopefully some day, the screens will have movies of high quality and substance like this to inspire us.

reviewText: My husband and I watched this last night and were very impressed and inspired by Temple Grandin who is the focus of this film. Having been diagnosed with autism in 1950 as a young child, Temple only began to speak (after lots of therapy) at the age of four. Temple was blessed with a supportive family and mentors in the form of teachers, therapists, etc. although she faced her share of prejudice and bullying, especially in middle and high school. Claire Danes portrays Temple with such insight and credibility that she is truly deserving of the Emmy award she won for this role.Temple Grandin's autism may have impaired her social skills somewhat, but what a brilliant mind! She invented the 'hug machine' for autistics who needed to be calmed when they were overstimulated, and she also developed ground-breaking methods for handling livestock, emphasizing humane handling. Today, Temple Grandin is a Professor at Colorado State University, and also a celebrated autism advocate.The movie, which is a semi-biographical account of Temple's early life and work in the field of livestock handling, manages to hit all the right notes. It is not sensational nor overly melodramatic and credibly portrays the struggles Temple faces on a daily basis as an autistic person. Things ordinary people take for granted, such as passing through an automatic sliding glass door, is portrayed as an almost insurmountable hurdle for Temple, who sees it as a guillotine! I loved the door metaphor which is used throughout the movie - each time Temple faces a challenge, she sees it as a door to be passed through to attain her objective! This is a must-see movie that will enable viewers to gain a deeper understanding of autism and its challenges.
summary: Insightful movie about an amazing woman with autism
